creator: gordont@gnf.org
text:
I have a content rewriting proxy that uses mod_ext_filter to rewrite 
content.
Everything was working beautifully on Apache 2.0.40. I upgraded to 2.0.42 
and using junk started to show up in my filter. I would get numbers showing 
up at the beginning and the end of the response. If I use a BrowserMatch to 
downgrade-1.0 for all cases, it seems to work. This leads me to believe 
that the bug is not in mod_ext_filter, but some interaction with the core.

This is very reproducable for me. I can even use a filter of /bin/cat and 
get this problem so I'm *certain* this is not my filter.

I'm out of town from 9/27 - 10/6 so I may to be able to respond to this bug 
immediately.

The URL shows a trace of 3 sessions, one 2.0.40 with HTTP/1.1, one 2.0.42 
with HTTP/1.1 (bugged), and one 2.0.42 with HTTP/1.0.

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
The bogus header you point out is really chunked transfer encoding, where 
instead of providing a content-length, the server will send chunks down to the
client, each prefixed with the length in hex, followed by CR-LF.  After all
data is sent, the 0<CR><LF> is sent to tell the client we're done.

This is not to say that it is ok for content filters to see that :)

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
file this under mod_proxy...  an output filter is not responsible for
ignoring the protocol data for chunked responses :)

creator: minfrin@sharp.fm
text:
Proxy (should) knows nothing about specific filters in the filter stack, and
should especially not know anything about chunked requests or responses.

Can it be confirmed whether this problem still exists in v2.0.45-dev?
Confirming on 2.0.45 release with mod_isapi on WindowsXP
creator: opaque@pub.to
opaque@pub.to
text:
Forgot to add this
OS --> All
Version --> 2.0.45
Reporter or someone could you edit summary?

I can't test 2.0.40 because Apache itself crashes with my ISAPI
extension cached in it.
Those headers appear at HTTP/1.1 requests randomly, rather than
seen in all 1.1 requests. It looks OK first, then reloading several
times you'll see chunked encoding headers added to the same page
that had no problem before. None of HTTP/1.0 requests get them.
The same ISAPI runs fine in other WWW servers.
I'm not sure if there's any mod_isapi specific problem or not.

text:
